documents.document: @sawngswjakec @adam_lewis But I dealt with it and then came to like it. Now pulp-free OJ does leave an odd taste in the mouth for me too...
@adam_lewis @sawngswjakec I once only liked pulp-free OJ. One day I bought pulpy OJ accidentally. I was weirded out by the pulp texture.
@barrysaunders @adam_lewis Don't know them! What were they like?
@davecarter That's right - they have Barnesy/INXS doing 'Good Times' and The Wrights doing 'Evie', not the originals.
@davecarter The UK/US rock canon is mostly 65-75 but it's more 76-86 in the Oz rock canon.
@davecarter Which is interesting cos The Easybeats and Thorpey at Sunbury are held up as epochal by a doco like Long Way To The Top.
@davecarter Boys In Town is their highest at #127...it's very very blokey.
@davecarter But also no Billy Thorpe or Easybeats in the entire list - very little 60s/early 70s stuff in that list (not enough sheen?)
@davecarter Of the top 100, the only post-1990 Aussie stuff is Baby Animals, Screaming Jets, Spiderbait's Black Betty, and Gotye/Kimbra.
@davecarter I reckon this 2014 MMM countdown is instructive as to the Oz Rock canon: https://t.co/expftdIyQ1
@barrysaunders @adam_lewis There's also heaps not on Spotify etc for licensing reasons or cos the record company has forgotten it exists.
@davecarter @staffo_sez And the production style of Mark Opitz, looking at his credits here: https://t.co/gGN9wgV5iW
@adam_lewis Mostly I was imagining a world where there's an established route for e.g. a Vic Simms or Screamfeeder reissue to get attention.
@davecarter @staffo_sez And it's basically mainstream music, or aiming to be, that could get into the charts (so add Powderfinger, Jet, etc)
@davecarter @staffo_sez Standard rock instruments, pop song structure, distinctive singer, ethos of masculine perhaps-larrikin mateship...
@awardtour What's the story there?
@_jbradley @staffo_sez The juxtaposition between who's on the rock Long Way To The Top doco and who's on the pop Love Is In The Air doco?
@staffo_sez I mean, the stereotype of Oz Rock in my head is ACDC, Angels, Chisel, Hunnas, Hoodoo Gurus, Mentals, Paul Kelly, etc.
@_jbradley @heckelfonic Side question: Who/what created the Oz rock canon? Is there anything more to it than 'what Triple M plays'?
@_jbradley @heckelfonic ...but I totally agree that their focus on dad-rock is almost comical these days.
@_jbradley @heckelfonic Oh, those mags very much push the 'this stuff you heard on the radio growing up is actually quite deep!' thing...
@adam_lewis But I do think Australia is missing a local Uncut/Mojo/Rolling Stone equivalent to push such claims to new generations.
@adam_lewis Honestly, I think critical consensus is that Don Walker, Paul Kelly, etc are geniuses, but maybe the public isn't there yet.
@gisellenguyen Yep: if yr body is adjusting to missing some mood-altering chemicals it got used to, odd moods are an obvious side effect.
@matt_levinson Also makes me wonder when Turnbull & co will follow suit with similar blanket policies to appease the hard right.
@matt_levinson Well, no. It does put a lie to the fig leaf of them doing it because they really care about stopping deaths at sea though.
@loadie All the way with DJT...
Pretty obvious that the price for the Oz government's support of this was Trump reaffirming America would take theâ€¦ https://t.co/k1riOIdMQB
Wasps are kind of evil, and evil wasps that eat other evil wasps from the inside are particularly so: https://t.co/YXFKxh3CJd
Modern rock is a niche now, where bands like Japandroids don't expect anything more than playing at middling venues: https://t.co/ksVl52lMdS
I felt more attuned to JJJ listener choices this year than the last few, but do largely agree with @BernardZuel : https://t.co/06CMLZfxgo
SBS's First Australians doco, on what happened on this day (and the aftermath) 229 years ago: https://t.co/g7Rt7IEi6l
How Flume's trademark drop became a cliche worldwide: https://t.co/3YPkpw4HCh
@sawngswjakec I liked this article explaining why they are so: https://t.co/8JCdB7N1K0
That very last computer-game sample thingy on Neil Cicierega's Shit ....what IS that?
@penelly @goldfishlaugh Like they've been pushing the bounds of civility and dominating meme culture. The meme encapsulates all that.
@penelly @goldfishlaugh imo the glee at the punch meme is cos it's such a perfect case of alt-right tools being used against them.
@nicilind That would have been awesome!
@nicilind I love the way that language holds the calcified remains of history.
@nicilind Thus Yuletide!
Great interview with Prince's 80s recording engineer Susan Rogers who went on to become a music psychologist! https://t.co/FEoYBc3F1s
@adam_lewis So I think calls of 'overrated' function like satire - works better when you're punching up & when your knowledge is first-hand.
@adam_lewis ..and lots of 34 year olds with fond memories of being 18 when Since I Left You came out who are now music reviewers *cough*
@adam_lewis And ofc it's easier for a record to have cultural capital when there's a major label (and a huge tech company) pushing it...
@adam_lewis In contrast, I think @heckelfonic was right to push back against Wildflower - she very clearly *got* what the record was about.
@adam_lewis So yr serious music bros saying, e.g., 'Lemonade is overrated' are usually really saying 'stuff not aimed at me is overrated'.
@adam_lewis IMO 'overrated' is an argument about what music we should pay attention to, & is often (but not always) about cultural capital.
@gisellenguyen So I wouldn't be surprised if they've spent their career trying to look like the Tenenbaums...
@gisellenguyen Angus Stone told me he called his home studios Belafonte Studios after the boat in The Life Aquatic.
@sawngswjakec And to calling every pop star who's maybe altered a lyric here or there a singer-songwriter. Very poptimist of them!
@staffo_sez It was meant to be! Clearly in the morning I am not capable of better descriptors than 'very nice'...
New Laura Marling track is inevitably very nice: https://t.co/bJNdxo2i6F
@_jbradley I find all this stuff really fascinating - the history of words can be very informative about how people lived!
@_jbradley But I reckon that there wasn't much impetus to define them until domestication - before that they'd have just been 'wild fowl'.
@_jbradley There have definitely been wild ducks swimming around in ponds since forever, and humans trying to eat them...
@_jbradley I figure in medieval Spain, the person asking you to serve duck for dinner is more likely to call it 'patt' rather than 'ente'.
@_jbradley This suggests ducks were widely domesticated in Europe only from the later middle ages: https://t.co/2o1R9sIQWZ
@_jbradley I wonder if Muslim Spain had a similar thing to the English thing with cow being Old English and beef being Norman French?
@_jbradley The English are very literal - famously everyone else in Europe calls pineapples something like 'ananas'!
@jonnoseidler I feel like the Quietuses of the world definitely aim at 30somethings keen to confirm their musical good taste as teens.
@jonnoseidler Yeah, you linked to it! The academic in me was just curious where that fact might have come from.
@_jbradley Whereas 'duck' replaced a word like 'ente' because the English called them, basically, birds that duck in the water?
@_jbradley Looks like the German/Italian words come from Latin, and the Spanish/Portuguese word comes from Arabic?
@jonnoseidler & this Liz Fraser/Jeff Buckleycollaboration that's floating around on the web is fab: https://t.co/RCyf24TM0i
@jonnoseidler She dicusses it in this Guardian interview: https://t.co/LVcMfxezky
1st year psychology textbooks often treat topics in biased ways and sometimes repeat myths: https://t.co/fzmu5vSN6o
@mlle_elle In 2016 terms, they'd be like if the Chainsmokers were as weird as Shia LaBeouf but still got Shania Twain to do a guest vocal.
My friend @drvickyw lists lots of interesting music psychology papers from 2016 (and congrats Vicky!): https://t.co/RirJZTr6Hs
Excellent look at the difference between good science and good TED-talk-about-science material. https://t.co/0GhQWMWL0A
In my lifetime, we've opened up to talking about mental illness, and Carrie Fisher was at the forefront of that: https://t.co/z78wWgzsYc
@gisellenguyen It's one of his very best too.
@penelly Was a pleasure to talk to your other two favourites! Both were unsurprisingly quite eloquent.
I wrote about some Aussie Christmas songs for the SMH, and talked to @timminchin and @darrenhanlon: https://t.co/363cbtAUAE
@Richaod Cat Power, probably? Like 'Cross Bones Style' circa 1998?
@HRobertsonEsq I mean, for Black Sheep, the Brian Wilson pastiche, they got in the actual Van Dyke Parks to columnate those ruins.
@HRobertsonEsq The soundtrack is also possibly the best thing about the movie apart from all the other best things. Let's Duet!
@HRobertsonEsq The Temptaaaations!
@sawngswjakec Is half of this just than individuals are more interesting than the average of individuals?
The Katering Show's advice column on how to deal with annoying Christmas things: https://t.co/zvT4EBwrfc
@quiteawful Ha, that millennial whoop thing shat me as well! I remember thinking it was very out of date + mountains/molehills.
I talked to Vice for a bit about pop and music psychology: https://t.co/B6ayltLiQC
An analysis of the 'pop-drop' that's now pretty close to being a cliche in pop: https://t.co/0BKrGqNYLR
Getting closer to understanding the evolution of whales: https://t.co/dMHAB5Uab9
The Sherlock Holmes of birds: https://t.co/qopmX1puE4
@obliviousgeek Haha, yeah, I'm starting to wonder if people are mostly replacing lost copies now...
I wrote this last year about the inescapability of Xmas Buble, and apparently it's just sold a million in AU, so: https://t.co/Ul9sE4Rkll
Awesome to see @RollingStoneAus giving @MarcusTeague a good amount of space to profile A.B. Original: https://t.co/Pse18qscBR
So many good Prince stories in this GQ article (including the truth about the Prince/Eddie Murphy basketball game): https://t.co/RzHy4EsZcb
Anwen Crawford eloquently muses on Dylan's Nobel Prize and the difference between poetry and pop lyrics: https://t.co/AYdbg7KuDN
The Onion headline: Exhausted Noam Chomsky Just Going To Try And Enjoy The Day For Once https://t.co/ISTkrPmTN2
Impulsiveness and selfishness are, neurally, two sides of the same coin: https://t.co/8vg4KD6zTx
@ohmiso Yep, the way that screwing workers/creating a monopoly is a basic business model these days is very troubling.
@ohmiso And all the stuff in @staffo_sez's explanation of why he quit taxis: https://t.co/IDRs4XqNol
@ohmiso It's cheap, gives the impression of being safer cos of driver ratings, and the app means you can see how far away the driver is.
Uber's business model is fairly obviously to drive taxis out of business and then jack up prices: https://t.co/eyZ8EVxaBu
Uber are not profitable, and their rides are so cheap because they're being subsidised by venture capital: https://t.co/eyZ8EVxaBu
@davecarter Yes, it's a very unorganic way to do it, and we humans are by definition organic!
@davecarter I have too many thoughts for a tweet or ten - I'll email - but in general he's pushing a point of view amongst many.
Andy Beta on the Tropicalia movement in Brazil and the way it disturbed the far right politics of the time: https://t.co/opvAjpn6un
What that duck-rabbit says about the way our brains work: https://t.co/wKburTYe36
